advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;UK ADVERT </strong></font><br><blockquote>One of the first advert for the Atari 520ST checked against an Apple Mac and an Apricot computer. <

computer.colors: 16 among 512 (320 x 200) / 4 among 512 (640 x 200) / monochrome (640 x 400) this last mode needs a special monitor.
computer.description:
The 520 ST featured same hardware basis and same amount of memory as the 260 ST.
The main difference between them was the built-in ROM TOS operating system and GEM Graphics Interface. In fact, the Atari 520ST originaly came with the OS on floppy as the OS was not completly finished. Very shortly afterward they came with the OS on 6 ROM chips (TOS 1.0).
It was first sold in Germany where it met a great success then released in the United States about six monts later. Colour and monochrome version were available. Sadly, users of the colour version couldn't expect programs written for the monochrome version to work until someone wrote an emulator allowing the software written for the monochrome version to run on a colour monitor.
Atari was the first company to offer built-in MIDI ports. This made the computer very popular with musicians. One game even used the MIDI conectors (Midi Maze) to connect up to 16 computers together in a MIDI network.
The 520 ST+ offered 1 MB of RAM instead of 512 KB. As the main board was designed to provide space for only 512 KB of RAM (16 x 41256 type chips), the second 512 KB bank chips were soldered on top of the original chips.
Apparently, 1 Mb versions were sold as Atari 1040s in Australia...
The model 520 STM came with a built-in TV modulator allowing a direct connection with the TV-set.
The original Atari 520 ST came with an external 360K single sided 3.5 floppy drive, the SF354. Most dealers either bundled it with separate power supply, or a much neater Cumana or Triangle branded drive at lower cost. _______________________

emulator.description: Hatari is an Atari ST emulator for Linux, BSD, BeOS, Mac OS X and other systems that are supported by the SDL library. More precisely, Hatari is an adaption of the WinSTon source code to the SDL library.
emulator.name: Hatari

item.description: 170Mb Quantum hard-drive||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;170MB QUANTUM HARD-DRIVE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This unit has an ICD Host Adapter.<
Atari Megafile 30||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;ATARI MEGAFILE 30</strong></font><br><blockquote>This hard-drive has a 30Mb capacity.<

Inside the Megafile 30||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;INSIDE THE MEGAFILE 30</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Seagate MFM 30 MB hard-disk Type ST-238<br> <b>(2)</b> Power supply<br> <b>(3)</b> Logical board<br> <b>(4)</b> Power and disk access LED's<br><
Memory expansion||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;MEMORY EXPANSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>512 KB to 2 MB memory expansion, depending of the memory chips used.<

Atari universal modem||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;ATARI UNIVERSAL MODEM</strong></font><br><blockquote>The SX212 modem was one of the rare Atari peripherals that could be used with all the Atari computers range, from the 400/800 series up to the Falcon. It had both the Atari I/O ports for the 8-bit systems and a standard RS-232 connector for ST's<br><br> It was a 300/1200 baud modem compatible with the well-known Hayes 'AT' commands.<br> Cable and software was sold separately, depending of the computer used. <

SML-804|||Laser printer|||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;SML-804</strong></font><br><strong>&gt;&nbsp;Laser printer</strong><br><blockquote>The SLM-804 was actually a Kyocera F1000 printer but without neither on-board processor and memory nor buttons other than the on/off switch. It was first delivered with the Mega ST but could be connected on all of the ST series computers through a dedicated interface box.<br> The printer used the processing power and the RAM memory of the ST computer for printing at 8 pages per minute and 300 DPI. The paper tray held 250 sheets.<

SMLC-804|||Laser printer interface|||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;SMLC-804</strong></font><br><strong>&gt;&nbsp;Laser printer interface</strong><br><blockquote>This interface allowed the SML-804 printer to be connected to any Atari ST holding at least 1 MB RAM.<

computer.keyboard: Full-stroke keyboard with numeric and editing keypads
computer.name: 520 ST / ST+ / STM
computer.ports: RGB, TV modulator (520STm), Cardridge, Midi (in/out), Centronics, RS232c, Hard Disk, Floppy Disk, Joystick, Mouse

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;ATARI 520 ST</strong></font><br><blockquote>it has the same characteristics as the 130 ST and the 260 ST, save for its added memory<

<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;520 ST MOTHERBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> SHIFTER custom circuit. Woks with the MMU to produce the video signal<br> <b>(2)</b> 512 KB RAM memory chips (256K x 1 bit)<br> <b>(3)</b> 2 x 6850 ACIA's. Manage asynchronous communications with keyboard, mouse, joysticks (first) and MIDI interface (second)<br> <b>(4)</b> YM-2149 sound generator chip (3 tones generator + noise generator)<br> <b>(5)</b> MMU custom circuit. Manages RAM address bus and video signal with the SHIFTER<br> <b>(6)</b> Motorola 68000 microprocessor<br> <b>(7)</b> GLUE custom chip. Manages the entire system and data transfer between various chips.<br> <b>(8)</b> Western Digital 1772 floppy disk controller chip. <br> <b>(9)</b> Multi-Function Peripheral 68901 chip. Performs a 8-bit parallel port, a built-in serial interface, timers and interrupts.<br> <b>(10)</b> DMA controller chip. Oversees data transfer from F.D. and H.D. drives and various peripherals<br> <b>(11)</b> 6 x ROM chips holding the BIOS and GEM operating system<br> <b>(12)</b> ROM cartridge connector<br> <b>(13)</b> Hard-disk unit DB19 connector<br> <b>(14)</b> Floppy-disc unit 15-pin DIN plug<br> <b>(15)</b> Modem/Serial DB25 connector<br> <b>(16)</b> Printer/Parallel DB25 connector<br> <b>(17)</b> RGB monitor DIN plug<br> <b>(18)</b> RF modulator and TV output chinch plug<br> <b>(19)</b> Musical interface MIDI in<br> <b>(20)</b> MIDI out<br> <b>(21)</b> Power DIN plug. Power is supplied by an external power supply unit<br> <b>(22)</b> Power On/Off switch<br> <b>(23)</b> System Reset switch<br> <b>(24)</b> 2 x joystick plugs <br><br> <b>Ari Feldman</b> specifies:<br><font color="#666666"> The "Shifter" and "Glue" chips were not coprocessors in the traditional sense. The base ST models had four custom chips:<br> * Shifter - Video<br> * DMA - DMA and bus access<br> * MMU - Memory access<br> * Glue - "glues" the operation of the other three chips together<br> Noe of these four chips could work independently. They were designed for very limited and specific functions and designed to only work with each other. For example, the Shifter woun't work without the MMU, etc.<br> Coprocessors wouldn't be added to the ST line until 1987/88 when the BLITTER chip arrived, which was basically a hardware implementation of the ST's RasterOps routines.</font> <

<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;REAR CONNECTORS</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> 2 x joysticks connectors<br> <b>(2)</b> Reset switch<br> <b>(3)</b> Power On/Off switch<br> <b>(4)</b> Power supply DIN plug<br> <b>(5)</b> MIDI out<br> <b>(6)</b> MIDI in<br> <b>(7)</b> TV RF output<br> <b>(8)</b> RGB video DIN plug<br> <b>(9)</b> Printer DB25 connector<br> <b>(10)</b> Modem DB25 connector<br> <b>(11)</b> Floppy-disc unit plug<br> <b>(12)</b> Hard-disk unit DB15 connector<
